                                                          Topics

                                                          Floating Point Arithmetic

                                                          • Representing numbers on a computer

                                                            E.g. None of the following can be represented exactly on a computer b/c binary representation does not terminate a string of bits

                                                            π=3.14159...

                                                            2=1.4142...

                                                            1/10

                                                          • Error propagation/rounding error

                                                            E.g. 4 digit mantissa computer with rounding (following called subtractive cancellation)

                                                            0.1234367←stored as 0.1234−0.1234216←stored as 0.1234−−−−−−0.0000151←computer gives 0

                                                          • Conditioning / stability

                                                            Measures how small changes (perturbations) in the initial input affects the general result

                                                            Conditioning refers to functions. Stability refers to algorithms.

                                                            E.g. subtractive cancellation is an unstable algorithm.

                                                            For functions F:R→R, cond(F) measures how changes in input affects output f(x). The smaller the better.

                                                          Linear Systems of Equations

                                                          Solve Ax→=b→ where A∈Rn×n, b→∈Rn, x→∈Rn

                                                          Direct method - Gaussian elimination

                                                          • process: factor A=LU where L∈Rn×n is a unit lower triangular matrix, U∈Rn×n is upper triangular
                                                          (LU)x⏟d=bLd=b←solve for d via forward eliminationUx=d←solve for x via backward substitution

                                                          Iterative method

                                                          • Write A=L+D+U where L is lower triangular, D is diagonal, U is upper triangular

                                                            (L+D+U)x=bLx+Dx+Ux=bDx=−(L+U)x+b=c←diagonal system, which ∈O(n)Dx(k+1)=−(L+U)xk+b←k = 0, 1, ... until convergence

                                                          • Start with an initial guess, typically x(0)=0

                                                          • How do we measure convergence?

                                                            X-test: ∥x(k+1)−x(k)∥< tolerance

                                                            F-test: ∥b−Ax(k)∥< tolerance

                                                          • Which test is more reliable?

                                                            Often use both tests. Use iterative refinement/improvement to possibly improve the computed solution x^

                                                          Non-linear Equations

                                                          • Solve F(x)=0 for x∗, which is the root of the equation

                                                            Is the equation linear? Is there a solution? How many solutions?

                                                            linear: F(x)=2x+7

                                                            non-linear: F(x)=2x2+7

                                                            non-linear: F(x)=x−e−x

                                                          • Algorithms based on the fixed point problem

                                                            F(x⏟root x*)=0⟺x=g(x⏟fixed point x*)

                                                            Can always use g(x)=x=F(x)g(x)=x−h(x)⋅F(x) where h(x) is the auxiliary function

                                                          • Fixed point iteration

                                                            Initial guess: x(0)=?, then iterate x(k+1)=g(x(k))

                                                            Newton's method for f(x)=0

                                                            xk+1=xk−F(xk)dFdxxk

                                                          Approximation / Interpolation

                                                          Data fitting

                                                          • Find a line that goes through 2 points (t0,y0),(t1,y1)

                                                            a0+a1t0=y0a0+a1t1=y1

                                                            OR Ax=b

                                                            [1t01t1][a0a1]=[y0y1]

                                                          • Find a line that goes through 3 points (t0,y0),(t1,y1),(t2,y2)

                                                            a0+a1t0=y0a0+a1t1=y1a0+a1t2=y2

                                                            OR Ax=b

                                                            [1t01t11t2][a0a1]=[y0y1y2]

                                                          • Non square

                                                            • overdetermined

                                                              • More rows than columns

                                                              • In general, no unique sol'n

                                                              • Look for best possible fit

                                                                ex. find a0,a1 s.t. ∥Ax−b∥ is minimized

                                                            • underdetermined

                                                              • More columns than rows

                                                              • In general, infinitely many solutions

                                                              • Look for a family of solutions

                                                                Or use piecewise interpolants (potential problem: piecewise interpolants are not smooth)

                                                            Numerical integration / quadrature

                                                            Problem: estimate ∫abf(x)dx

                                                            Base idea: integrate piecewise and sum the areas

                                                          Linear Systems

                                                          Relative Residual vs Relative Error

                                                          Because of machine round off error,

                                                          • PA=LU becomes P^(A+E)=L^U^, where P^,L^,U^ are the computed factors.
                                                          • Then solving Ax→=b→ becomes solving (A+E)x^=b→, where x^ is the computed solution.
                                                          • Letting Ex^=r→, (A+E)x^=b→ becomes Ax^+r→=b→, where r→=b→−Ax^ is the residual. (We would like this to be 0→ ).

                                                          We can show that if row partial pivoting is used, the error and relative residual ∥r→∥∥b→∥ are bounded

                                                          • ∥E∥≲k⋅eps⋅∥A∥ where k is not too large and depends on n.
                                                          • ∥r→∥≲k⋅eps⋅∥b→∥⟺∥r→∥∥b→∥≲k⋅eps

                                                          However, this does not mean that ∥x→−x^∥ or relative error ∥x→−x^∥∥x→∥ is small.

                                                          What's the relationship between relative error and relative residual?

                                                          We have {Ax→=b→Ax^=b→−r→⟺A(x→−x^)=r→

                                                          Derive upper bound:

                                                          • x→−x^=A−1r→⟺∥x→−x^∥=‖A−1r→‖≤‖A−1‖∥r→∥
                                                          • b→=Ax→⟺∥b→∥=∥Ax→∥≤∥A∥∥x→∥

                                                          Combining the above: ∥x→−x^∥∥A∥∥x→∥≤‖A−1‖∥r→∥∥b→∥⟺∥x→−x^∥∥x→∥≤∥A∥‖A−1‖∥r→∥∥b→∥ where ∥A∥‖A−1‖=cond(A)

                                                          Derive a lower bound:

                                                          • r→=A(x→−x^)⟺∥r→∥≤∥A∥∥x→−x^∥
                                                          • x→=A−1b→⟺∥x→∥≤‖A−1‖∥b→∥

                                                          Combining the above: ∥A∥∥x→−x^∥∥x→∥≥∥r→∥‖A−1‖∥b→∥⟺∥x→−x^∥∥x→∥≥∥r→∥∥b→∥∥A∥‖A−1‖

                                                          Combining:

                                                          we have ∥r→∥∥b→∥cond(A)≤∥x→−x^∥∥x→∥≤cond(A)∥r→∥∥b→∥

                                                          If cond(A) is very large, problem is poorly conditioned. Small relative residual does not mean small relative error (the bounds are large).

                                                          If the cond(A) is not too large, the problem is well conditioned and the small relative residual is a reliable indicator of small relative error.

                                                          Conditioning is a continuous spectrum, how large is "very large" depends on context.

                                                          Example

                                                          [0.7800.5630.9130.656]x→=[0.2170.254], we know true solution is x→=[1−1]

                                                          Consider two computed solutions, x^1=[0.999−1.001],x^2=[0.341−0.087]

                                                          r→1=b→−Ax^1=[−0.001243−0.001572],r→2=b→−Ax^2=[−0.0000010]

                                                          ∥x→−x1^∥∥x∥ is much smaller than ‖x→−x2^‖∥x∥ as expected (since x^2 is a terrible solution) , but ‖r→1‖∥b→∥ is much larger than ‖r→2‖∥b→∥.

                                                          ⟹ relative residual is not a reliable indicator of relative error.

                                                          Let's take a look at cond(A).

                                                          A−1=106[0.656−0.565−0.9130.780], where 106=1det(A)

                                                          ∥A∥∞=1.572,‖A−1‖∞=1.693⋅106⇒cond∞(A)=∥A∥∞‖A−1‖∞=2.66⋅106

                                                          ∥x→−x^∥∥x→∥≤2.66⋅106∥r∥∥b∥, i.e. relative error in could be as big as 2.66⋅106 times the relative residual.

                                                          Thus this is a poorly conditioned matrix.

                                                          Iterative Improvement

                                                          Can we improve x^ ? One easy way is to improve mantissa length.

                                                          We want to solve Ax→=b→, having already solved (A+E)x^=b→ or Ax^+r→=b→

                                                          Subtracting the two equations yields A(x→−x^)=r→, so we let z→=x→−x^, and solve Az→=r→

                                                          Then x→=x^+z→, but this is a fallacy since we can not solve for z→ exactly. Thus we get z^, and not z→.

                                                          But if we were to get 2 leading digits correct in x^, then we will get 2 leading digits correct in z^, and then we will have 4 leading digits correct in x^+z^

                                                          The Algorithm

                                                          Compute x^(0) by solving Ax→=b→ in a floating point system.

                                                          For i=0,1,2,… until solution is good enough (or until convergence failure)

                                                          1. Compute the residual: r(i)=b−Ax^(i)
                                                          2. Solve Az→(i)=r(i) For some z^(i)=x−xi
                                                          3. Update x^(i+1)=x^(i)+z^(i)

                                                          Why is xi+1 better than xi?

                                                          x1 is the first element of x where Ax=b and x1=.d1d2d3d4...

                                                          In the first iteration we get x01=.d1d2d~3d~4...

                                                          z0 is solved from Az0=r0

                                                          z0=0.00z3z4z~5z~6

                                                          x1=x0+z0=0.d1d2d~3d~4+0.00z3z4z~5z~6

                                                          since z3=d3−d~3 and z4=d4−d~4

                                                          we have that x1=.d1d2(d~3+z3)⏟d3(d~4+z4)⏟d4

                                                          Non Linear Equations

                                                          Fixed Point Iteration

                                                          Problem: F:R→R

                                                          We need to some F(x~)=0 for some x~∈R (root finding problem)

                                                          Typically, we cannot find a "closed form" (analytic) solution to non linear F, which is why we need numerical techniques.

                                                          We can find iterative methods which generate an approximation xk^,k=0,1,2,… such that xk^→x~ as k→∞

                                                          Fixed Point Methods

                                                          Given a root finding problem, F(x~)=0, this is equivalent to a fixed point problem x~=g(x~), where x~ is a fixed under g

                                                          Example: F(x)=x−e−x, this is equivalent to finding the fixed point of x=e−x

                                                          We often use the algebraically equivalent fixed point problem to solve the root finding problem because there is an obvious iteration algorithm to do so.

                                                          To obtain a working g(x), we can use 2 forms:

                                                          • g(x)=x−F(x)←first form

                                                            • F(x~)=0⇔x~=g(x~)

                                                          • g(x)=x−h(x)F(x)←second form

                                                            • F(x~)=0⇒x~=g(x~), however we can have a fixed point x~=g(x~) such that h(x~)=0 but F(x~)≠0
                                                            • Advantage: there is flexibility in designing g(x) to make iteration converge faster.

                                                          Start with an approximate solution x0^ then iterate: xk+1^=g(xk^),k=0,1,2,… until convergence/failure.

                                                          Example: Let F(x)=x2+2x−3 with exact roots x~=1,−3

                                                          Consider the fixed point iteration (FPI): xk+1=xk+xk2+2xk−3xx2−5 for the fixed point problem x=g(x)=x+x2+2x−3x2−5

                                                          We see that this is the second form of the fixed point problem, where h(x)=−1x2−5

                                                          FPI of x0^=−5→xk^ converges to −3.

                                                          However, FPI of x0^=5→xk^ does not converge. We can keep trying, but that would be a significant waste of time.

                                                          Fixed Point Theorem

                                                          If there is an interval [a,b] such that  ∀ x∈[a,b]

                                                          • g(x)∈[a,b]
                                                          • |g′(x)|≤L<1

                                                          then g(x) has a unique fixed point in [a,b]

                                                          Proof

                                                          Recall the Mean Value Theorem (MVT)

                                                          If f is continuous on [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b), then ∃ c s.t. f′(c)=f(b)−f(a)b−a

                                                          ⟺f(b)−f(a)=f′(c)(b−a)

                                                          Start with any x0^∈[a,b] and iterate with x^k+1=g(xk^),k=0,1,2… , then all xk^∈[a,b]

                                                          Moreover, by the MVT, we have that for some ηk∈[xk−1,xk]⊂[a,b]

                                                          xk+1−xk=g(xk)−g(xk−1)=g′(ηk)(xk−xk−1)|xk+1−xk|≤|g′(ηk)||xk−xk−1|≤L|xk−xk−1|≤⋯≤Lk|x1−x0|

                                                          As k→∞, RHS →0 since L<1, so LHS |xk+1−xk|→0

                                                          This means the fixed points are converging to some x~∈[a,b]

                                                          To complete this proof, we must show:

                                                          1. x~=g(x~) (i.e., x~ is a fixed point!)
                                                          2. x~ is unique in [a,b]

                                                          Example How do we use FPT?

                                                          F(x)=x−ex=0 and g(x)=e−x for x=g(x)

                                                          What is the maximum interval of guaranteed convergence of xk ?

                                                          Rate of Convergence

                                                          We have -th order convergence to fixed point x~ if limxk→x~|x~−xk+1||x~−xk|p=c≠0

                                                          Example: Table of absolute error of iterates, |x~−xk|

                                                          We see that the second column converges much much faster.

                                                          Thm (FPI Convergence)

                                                          For the Fixed Point Iteration xk+1=g(xk), we have -th order convergence to x^ if g′(x^)=g′′(x^)⋯=g(p−1)(x^)=0 but gp(x^)≠0

                                                          Proof

                                                          Recall: the Taylor series of a function is an infinite sum of terms that are expressed in terms of the function's derivatives at a single point.

                                                          ∑n=0∞f(n)(a)n!(x−a)n=f(a)+f′(a)1!(x−a)+f′′(a)2!(x−a)2+f′′′(a)3!(x−a)3+⋯

                                                          So letting xk+1=g(xk)=g(x~+(xk−x~)), its Taylor expansion is

                                                          xk+1=g(x~)+(xk−x~)g′(x~)+(xk−x~)22!g′′(x~)+⋯+(xk−x~)p−1(p−1)!g(p−1)(x~)+(xk−x~)pp!g(p)(ηk)

                                                          where ηk∈[x~,xk]

                                                          However, if g′(x^)=g′′(x^)=⋯=g(p−1)(x^)=0 , the Taylor expansion yields

                                                          xk+1=g(x^)+(xk−x^)pp!g(p)(ηk)⇔xk+1−g(x^)(xk−x^)p=1p!g(p)(ηk)⇔xk+1−x^(xk−x^)p=1p!g(p)(ηk)

                                                          We see that as k→∞,xk→x^,ηk∈[x^,xk]→x^

                                                          We can rewrite this as

                                                          limxk→x^|xk+1−x^||xk−x^|p=1p!g(p)(x^)≠0

                                                          Thus we see that when the p-th derivative of g at x^ is not zero, we reach p-th order convergence.

                                                          We see that now we can use the second form of the fixed point iteration g(x)=x−h(x)F(x) to accelerate iteration by picking a h(x) such that the p-th derivative of g is not zero at x^.

                                                          Newton's Method

                                                          For xk+1=xk−F(xk)F′(xk)

                                                          root finding problem of F(x)=0⟺x=g(x) with g(x)=x−F(x)F′(x)

                                                          This is the second form of the fixed point problem with h(x)=1F′(x)

                                                          Speed of Newton's Method

                                                          Suppose that F′(x~)=0 but F′′(x~)≠0

                                                          g′(x)=1−F′(x)F′(x)−F(x)F′′(x)(F′(x))2=F(x)F′′(x)(F′(x))2

                                                          so g′(x~)=0 for any function F.

                                                          By rate of convergence theorem, Newton's method has at least quadratic convergence (p=2), since g′(x~)=0 for any function F

                                                          Geometric Interpretation of Newton's Method

                                                          To solve F(x)=0 at an initial guess xk , we can approximate (or model) F(x) by a linear polynomial p(x) that satisfies conditions: p(xk)=F(xk) and p′(xk)=F′(xk)

                                                          Recall MVT: f(b)−f(a)=f′(c)(b−a)⟺f(b)=f(a)+(b−a)f′(c)

                                                          So we have the following polynomial

                                                          pk(x)=F(xk)+(x−xk)F′(xk)

                                                          xk+1 is the root of pk(x), i.e. pk(xk+1)=0

                                                          ⇒F(xk)+(xk+1−xk)F′(xk)=0⇒xk+1=xk−F(xk)F′(xk)

                                                          Note Newton's Method does not always converge.

                                                          Example Newton's method on F(x)=x−e−x

                                                          xk+1=xk−F(xk)F′(xk)=xk−xk−e−xk1+e−xk=(1+xk)e−xk1+e−xk

                                                          Secant Method

                                                          Recall NM: xk+1=xk−F(xk)F′(xk), notice that we have to supply the first derivative of F

                                                          We can approximate F′(xk) by F(xk)−F(xk−1)xk−xk−1, then

                                                          xk+1=xk−F(xk)(xk−xk−1)F(xk)−F(xk−1)

                                                          Another way to derive this is using the geometric interpretation.

                                                          pk(x)=F(xk)+(x−xk)F′(xk)=F(xk)+(x−xk)F(xk)−F(xk−1)xk−xk−1

                                                          Let xk+1 be the root of pk(x), i.e. pk(xk+1)=0=F(xk)+(xk+1−xk)F(xk)−F(xk−1)xk−xk−1

                                                          However, this is not a fixed point iteration of the form xk+1=g(xk), as no function g could support two values.

                                                          We cannot directly use FPT or RCT to analyze this method. However, with some adjustments we can prove rate of convergence is p=1+52≈1.62

                                                          Super Linear Convergence

                                                          Newton's Method: xk+1=xk−F(xk)F′(xk)←p=2

                                                          Secant Method: xk+1=xk−F(xk)F(xk)−F(xk−1)xk−xk−1=xk−F(xk)(xk−xk−1)F(xk)−F(xk−1)←p=1.62

                                                          But we see that Newton's method requires 2 Function evaluations per step as F,F′ are not the same.

                                                          And the secant method requires only 1 function evaluation. Although F(x) needs to be evaluated, F(xk−1) has been computed during the previous iteration!

                                                          Effective rate of convergence takes cost per iteration into account, as well as speed. Thus secant method is "effectively" faster than Newton's method.

                                                          Bisection Method

                                                          Oftentimes, if we start Newton's/Secant method with the wrong initial guess, they will not converge (wrong side of the hill). Bisection Method however has guaranteed convergence, this is to say that it always finds a root, but slowly.

                                                          We need to find an a≤b such that F(a)≤0≤F(b) or F(b)≤0≤F(a). This way, there is at least one root of F in [a,b]

                                                          Assume F(a)≤0≤F(b), we loop until b−a is small enough:

                                                          Let m=(a+b)/2. If F(m)≤0 then set a=m, else b=m

                                                          Repeat for the interval [m,b] or [a,m]

                                                          Then we have linear rate of convergence p=1,c=12 with guaranteed convergence.

                                                          Hybrid Method

                                                          We can start off with slow reliable methods (e.g. bisection), then switch to a faster one that requires a more accurate initial guess.

                                                          Example: Combine Bisection and Newton's Method

                                                          System of Non-Linear Equations

                                                          We want to solve F(x→)=0→

                                                          where F(x→)=[F1(x1,x2)F2(x1,x2)]=[4(x1)2+9(x2)2−16x1−54x2+61x1x2−2x1−1]=[00]

                                                          Recall Newton's Method for a single non linear equation where F:R→R and xk+1=xk−F(xk)F′(xk)

                                                          Then for F:Rn→Rn, xk+1=xk→−F(xk→)F′(xk→)

                                                          Note F′ is the Jacobian matrix of F, i.e. F′∈Rn×n

                                                          xk+1→=xk→−[F′(xk→)]−1F(xk→)[F′(xk→)](xk+1→−xk→)=−F(xk→)

                                                          This is simply in the form of some Ax→=b→, a linear system!

                                                          This is very expensive! We can use the Pseudo Newton Method by holding the Jacobian matrix fixed for a few iterations, so that we can reuse the PA=LU factorization. This is alright so long as we are still converging.

                                                          Approximation/Interpolation

                                                          Approximation Methods

                                                          Truncated Taylor Series

                                                          Find Taylor expansion for F(x)

                                                          F(x)=F(a)+F′(a)1!(x−a)+F′′(a)2!(x−a)2+F′′′(a)3!(x−a)3+⋯

                                                          Approximate it by truncating at n

                                                          p(x)=F(a)+F′(a)(x−a)+⋯+F(n)(a)n!(x−a)n

                                                          then the error can be expressed as

                                                          e(x)=p(x)−F(x)=F(n+1)(η)(n+1)!(x−a)n+1

                                                          Interpolation

                                                          Find a polynomial such that p(xi)=F(xi),i=0,1,2,…

                                                          F is the function we are trying to approximate, could simply be a set of data.

                                                          Least Squares

                                                          Find a polynomial such that p(x) minimizes ∥F−p∥2=(∫ab(F(x)−p(x))2dx)1/2

                                                          Other norms we can use for Least Squares approximation:

                                                          ∥F−p∥∞=maxa≤x≤b|F(x)−p(x)|

                                                          ∥F−p∥1=∫ab|F(x)−p(x)|dx

                                                          Polynomial Interpolation

                                                          Consider Pn : the set of all polynomials of degree ≤n

                                                          It is a function space of dimension n+1, i.e., it requires a basis of n+1 functions.

                                                          The most common basis is the monomial basis {xi}i=0n

                                                          i.e. it spans Pn and the xi are linearly independent (∑i=0naixi=0 ∀ x⟹ai=0 ∀ i)

                                                          Note we can shift the basis {(xα)i:i=0,1,...,n}

                                                          Weierstrass' Theorem (Existence)

                                                          If a function F is continuous on an interval [a,b], then for any ϵ>0, ∃ pϵ s.t. ‖F−pϵ‖∞<ϵ

                                                          I.e. for any continuous function on a closed interval [a,b], there exists some polynomial that is as close to it as it can be.

                                                          Numerical Methods for Polynomial Interpolation

                                                          3 bases - Monomial, Lagrange, and Newton

                                                          Monomial Basis

                                                          a.k.a Vandermonde Method or Method of Undetermined Coefficients

                                                          Theorem

                                                          For any sets: {xi:i=0,1,…n},{yi:i=0,1,…,n} for distinct xi s and indistinct yi s

                                                          ∄ p(x)∈Pn s.t. p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,…,n

                                                          Proof

                                                          If such p(x) exists, it must be possible to write it as a monomial space polynomial p(x)=∑i=0naixi

                                                          Then we have n+1 unknowns, {ai},i=0,1,…,n

                                                          We need n+1 equations to solve for the ai's

                                                          We can convert it into a matrix problem with p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,…n

                                                          Vandermonde Matrix
                                                          Va=y[(x0)0(x0)1(x0)2…(x0)n(x1)0(x1)1(x1)2…(x1)n⋮(xn)0(xn)1(xn)2…(xn)n][a0a1⋮an]=[y0y1⋮yn]

                                                          The question now reduces to checking whether V is invertible/non-singular.

                                                          V is singular iff ∃ a→≠0 s.t. Va→=0

                                                          We can return to polynomial problem, we are asking if it's possible for p∈Pn s.t. p(xi)=0,i=0,1,2,…,n

                                                          If has n+1 roots ⟹p(xi)=0 ∀ x⟹a→=0⟹V is singular

                                                          But this is impossible as no polynomial in Pn can have n+1 roots

                                                          Alternatively, since {xi} are distinct, we have det(V)=(−1)n+1∏i=1n∏j=0i−1(xi−xj)≠0⟹V is non-singular

                                                          The Vandermonde matrix proves existence, but it does not lead to the best algorithm - it can be poorly conditioned, and the PV=LU factorization plus forward/backward solve will be costly.

                                                          Lagrange Basis

                                                          Consider a simple interpolation problem p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,…,n

                                                          Consider the basis {li(x)} where li(x)=∏j=0,j≠inx−xjxi−xj for i=0,1,…,n

                                                          Note, li(x)∈Pn,∀i and li(xj)={1i=j0i≠j

                                                          With this basis function, we can write out the interpolating polynomial for free, but it is prohibitively expensive to evaluate at non-interpolation points

                                                          p(x)=∑i=0nli(x)yi⟹p(x)∈Pn and p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,…,n

                                                          Newton Basis

                                                          For simple interpolation p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,…,n, we look for an interpolating p(x) of the form:

                                                          p(x)=a0+a1(x−x0)+a2(x−x0)(x−x1)+⋯+an(x−x0)(x−x1)…(x−xn−1)

                                                          Converting into a matrix, we have

                                                          [100…01(x1−x0)0⋯01(x2−x0)(x2−x0)(x2−x1)⋯0⋮1(xn−x0)…∏i=0n−1(xn−xi)][a0a1a2⋮an]=[y0y1y2⋮yn]

                                                          This is a lower triangular system, which means there is no factorization involved.

                                                          a0=y0a1=y1−y0x1−x0a2=y2−y1x2−x1−y1−y0x1−x0x2−x0

                                                          We notice a pattern, defined below.

                                                          Divided Difference
                                                          y[x1]=y(x1)=y1y[xi+k,…,xi]=y[xi+k,…,xi+1]−y[xi+k−1,…,xi]xi+k−xie.g.y[x2,x1,x0]=y[x2,x1]−y[x1,x0]x2−x0

                                                          The polynomial is thus given by

                                                          p(x)= y[x0]+(x−x0)y[x1,x0]+(x−x0)(x−x1)y[x2,x1,x0]+⋯+(x−x0)...(x−xn−2)y[xn−1,…,x0]+(x−x0)…(x−xn−1)y[xn,…,x0]

                                                          Then, p(x)∈Pn and p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,…,n

                                                          Proof by Induction let p(x)≡pn(x)

                                                          Basis: n=0

                                                          p0(x)=y[x0]

                                                          p0(x0)=y[x0]=y0

                                                          Basis: n=1

                                                          p1(x)=y[x0]+(x−x0)y[x1,x0]

                                                          p1(x0)=y[x0]=y0

                                                          p1(x1)=y[x0]+(x1−x0)(y1−y0x1−x0)=y[x0]+y1−y0=y1

                                                          Induction hypothesis

                                                          1. pn−1(x)∈pn is the unique polynomial of degree ≤n that satisfies pn−1(xi)=yi,i=0,1,...,n−1

                                                            pn−1(x)=y[x0]+(x−x0)y[x1,x0]+(x−x0)(x−x1)y[x2,x1,x0]+...+(x−x0)(x−x1)...(x−xn−2)y[xn−1,...,x0]

                                                          2. q(x)∈pn−2 is the unique polynomial of degree ≤n−1 that satisfies q(xi)=yi,i=0,...,n

                                                            pn−1(x)=y[x1]+(x−x2)y[x2,x1]+(x−x1)(x−x2)y[x3,x2,x1,x0]+...+(x−x1)(x−x2)...(x−xn−1)y[xn,...,x0]

                                                            Note q(x) is just pn−1(x) with the data shifted xi→xi+1

                                                          Induction step

                                                          Consider pn(x)=pn−1(x)+(x−x0)(x−x1)...(x−xn−1)an

                                                          Clearly, pn(xi)=pn−1(xi)=yi for i=0,1,...,n−1

                                                          Need to choose an s.t. pn(xn)=yn

                                                          Consider r(x)=(x−x0)q(x)−(x−xn)pn−1(x)xn−x0

                                                          Clearly, r(x0)=pn−1(x0)=y0 by IH1, and r(xn)=q(xn)=yn by IH2

                                                          and for i=1,2,...,n−1, r(xi)=(xi−x0)yi−(xi−xn)yixn−x0=yi

                                                          Also r(x)∈Pn, so r(x) is the unique polynomial of degree ≤n that satisfies r(xi)=yi,i=0,...,n

                                                          If pn(x)=pn−1(x)+(x−x0)(x−x1)...(x−xn−1)an also satisfies pn(xi)=yi,i=0,...,n, then we must have that pn(x)=r(x)

                                                          Coefficient of xn in pn(x) is an

                                                          Coefficient of xn in r(x) is y[xn..x1]−y[xn−1...x0]xn−x0=y[xn...x0]

                                                          Hence an=y[xn...x0] and pn(x)=pn−1(x)+(x−x0)(x−x1)...(x−xn−1)y[xn...x0]

                                                          E.g. Find a p∈P3 s.t. p(0)=1,p(1)=3,p(2)=9,p(3)=25

                                                          Divided difference table

                                                          p(x)=y[x0]+(x−x0)y[x1,x0]+(x−x0)(x−x1)y[x2,x1,x0]+(x−x0)(x−x1)y[x3,x2,x1,x0]=1+2x+2(x)(x−1)+x(x−1)(x−2)

                                                          Osculatory Interpolation (interpolation with derivatives)

                                                          How are divided differences and derivatives related?

                                                          For y[x1,x0]=y(x1)−y(x0)x1−x0, we have

                                                          limx1→x0y[x1,x0]=limx1→x0y(x1)−y(x0)x1−x0=y′(x0)

                                                           

                                                          For , we have

                                                          limx2→x0x1→x0y[x2,x1,x0]=limx1→x0y[x2,x1]−y[x1,x0]x2−x0=y′′(x0)2!

                                                           

                                                          We can show that in general

                                                          limxk→x0xk−1→x0⋮x1→x0y[xk,xk−1,…x0]=y(k)(x0)k!

                                                          Example: Find p∈P4 such that

                                                          p(0)=0

                                                          p(1)=1,p′(1)=1,p′′(1)=2

                                                          p(2)=6

                                                          p(x)=y[0]+xy[1,0]+x(x−1)y[1,1,0]+x(x−1)2y[1,1,1,0]+x(x−1)3y[2,1,1,1,0]=0+x+x(x−1)2+x(x−1)3

                                                          Error in Polynomial Interpolation

                                                          E(x)=y(x)−p(x)

                                                          For simple interpolation, p(xi)=yi,i=0,1,...,n, we can show that

                                                          E(x)=y(n+1)(n+1)!(η)∏i=0n(x−xi)

                                                          where η∈sp{x0,...,xn,x}=[min{x0,...,xn,x},max{x0,...,xn,x}]

                                                          Runge Phenomenon

                                                          Problem of oscillation at the edges of an interval that occurs when interpolating with polynomials of high degree over a set of equispaced points - going to higher degrees does not always improve accuracy!

                                                          Below is the plot of the Runge function f(x)=11+25x2 interpolated at equidistant xi∈[−1,1] s.t. xi=2in−1,i∈{0,1,…,n}

                                                          Solution: piecewise interpolation

                                                          Numerical Integration

                                                          Quadrature is a historical term which refers to the process of determining area.

                                                          Problem: Approximate some I(F)=∫abF(x)dx

                                                          Recall: Riemann Sums of a function F

                                                          R(F)=∑i=0u−1F(ηi)(xi+1−xi)

                                                          Composite Rule: Apply a simple formula like above on many short integrals, i.e. ∫x1x2F(x)dx

                                                          Basic Formulas: Based on interpolating quadrature (instead of integrating we determine area using the interpolated polynomial)

                                                          We approximate F(x) by some p(x) on [a,b] (or [xi,xi+1]). In Lagrange form, p(x)=∑0nF(xi)li(x)

                                                          I(F)≈Q(F)=I(P)=∫abp(x)dx=∫ab[∑i=0nF(xi)li(x)]=∑i=0nF(xi)∫abli(x)dx⏟Ai=∑i=0nAiF(xi)

                                                          This is the standard form of quadrature. The Ai are weights, and xi are nodes.

                                                          Q(F) is a linear operator. I.e. Q(αf+g)=αQ(F)+Q(g) for functions f and g

                                                          If Q(F) integrates 1,x,x2,...,xn exactly, then Q(F) integrates all polynomials of degree ≤n exactly.

                                                          Theorem: Existence of Interpolatory Quadrature

                                                          Given any set of n+1 distinct nodes, we can choose the weights Ai such that the quadrature rule is exact for all polynomials of degree ≤n, moreover Ai 's are unique.

                                                          Proof Since Q(F) is linear, we need only show Q is exact for {xi}i=0n. I.e., for each xk, we need to show

                                                          Q(xk)=∑i=0nAi(xi)k=1k+1(bk+1−ak+1)

                                                          This results in n+1 equations with n+1 unknowns.

                                                          [111…1x0x1x2…xn(x0)2(x1)2(x2)2⋯(xn)2⋮⋮⋮…⋮(x0)n(x1)n(x2)n⋯(xn)n][A0A1A2⋮An]=[(b−a)/1(b2−a2)/2(b3−a3)/3⋮(bn+1−an+1)/(n+1)]

                                                          We see that the first matrix is simply the transposed Vandermonde Matrix, thus by invertibility, weights are unique.

                                                          Definition of Precision

                                                          If m is the highest natural number such that Q integrates all polynomials of degree ≤m, we say the precision of Q is m.

                                                          Notation: I for integral

                                                          Midpoint Rule: I(F)≈Q(F)=M(F)=I(p0)=(b−a)F(a+b2)

                                                          Note The degree of interpolating polynomial n = 0, but precision is higher

                                                          M(x0)=M(1)=b−1=I(1)

                                                          M(x1)=(b−a)(a+b2)=b2−a22=I(x)

                                                          M(x2)=(b−a)(a+b2)2≠b3−a33=I(x2)

                                                          Trapezoid Rule: I(F)≈Q(F)=T(F)=I(p1)=b−a2[F(a)+F(b)]

                                                          Note The degree of interpolating polynomial n = 1

                                                          T(x0)=(b−a)(1+12)=b−1=I(1)

                                                          T(x1)=(b−a)(a+b2)=b2−a22=I(x)

                                                          T(x2)=(b−a)(a2+b22)≠b2−a23=I(x2)

                                                          Simpson's Rule: I(F)≈Q(F)=S(F)=I(p2)=b−a6[F(a)+4F(b+a2)+F(b)]

                                                          Exercise: Write this in standard form (weight times node)

                                                          Note The degree of interpolating polynomial n = 2

                                                          Complete precision analysis on our own

                                                          Derivation: 2M+T3

                                                          Error in Interpolatory Quadrature

                                                          En=I(F)−Qn(F)=∫ab[F(x)−pn(x)]dx=∫ab(F(n+1)(η)(n+1)!∏i=0n(x−xi))dx←sub in polynomial interpolation error

                                                          Will interpolatory quadrature rules converge to I(F) as n→∞ ?

                                                          Theorem Let F be continuous on [a,b] and Qn(F)=∑i=0nAi(n)F((xi)(n))

                                                          Then limn→∞Qn(F)=I(F)⟺∃k∈R,∋:∑i=0n|Ai(n)|≤k,∀n∈N
